* WHEN...Until 1027 PM PST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 6 at 7:12PM HST until March 7 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY FOR BIG ISLAND SUMMITS REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST THURSDAY...
.Deep moisture moving over the Big Island from the east will lead to periods of freezing rain and snow over the summits and upper slopes of Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa.
* WHAT...Freezing rain and snow. Additional ice accumulations of around one quarter of an inch. Snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches.
* WHERE...Big Island Summits.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 6 at 7:01PM HST until March 6 at 10:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall.
* WHERE...The island of Oahu in Honolulu County.
* WHEN...Until 1000 PM HST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding on roads, poor drainage areas, and in streams.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 658 PM HST, radar indicated heavy showers, and a few thunderstorms, moving over northern and northeastern Oahu. Showers have been especially persistent from Waikane to Kahuku to Haleiwa, with peak rain rates near 2 inches per hour producing very low visibility. Although showers are moving quickly westward, additional heavy showers are approaching from the east. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hauula, Punaluu, Laie, Wahiawa, Kaaawa, Waikane, Mililani, Kahuku, Waiahole, Kahaluu, Haleiwa, Ahuimanu, Kahana Valley State Park, Helemano Housing, Whitmore Village, Malaekahana State Park, Waimea Valley, Kualoa, Pupukea and Waimea Bay.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 7 at 2:23PM ChST until March 11 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 9 to 11 feet at Kosrae. Large breaking waves of 10 to 13 feet over the weekend at Majuro.
* WHERE...East facing reefs of Kosrae. North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM ChST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is possible starting Friday, especially during high tide. Greatest risk will be around the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher around the Marshall Islands.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 6 at 8:42PM MST until March 8 at 11:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 4 inches except between 4 and 9 inches above 7500 feet possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass.
* WHEN...From Thursday afternoon through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Tire traction will be reduced. Extend the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. This includes along portions of I-25. Gusty northeast winds could bring down tree branches. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Most of the snow accumulation will occur Friday morning through the afternoon. Reduced visibility from blowing snow is possible through Friday night, even after snow has ended.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 6 at 10:37PM EST by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Boston/Norton MA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Massachusetts...
Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire Counties.
Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire Counties.
Taunton River Near Bridgewater affecting Bristol and Plymouth Counties.
For the Connecticut River...including Montague, Northampton, Holyoke Dam, Holyoke, Springfield, Thompsonville, Hartford, Middle Haddam... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Taunton River...including Bridgewater...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Taunton River near Bridgewater.
* WHEN...From Thursday afternoon until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Minor lowland and backyard flooding is likely along reaches of the river along Bridgewater and Middleboro. Backwater flooding from the Taunton River will cause prolonged flooding of lower Purchade Brook in Middleboro. This will cause Woloski Park to become impassable by vehicles for days. Beware of the dangers of crossing flooded roadways- the water may be deeper than you think. Floodwaters have the ability to damage roadways. Heed the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 PM EST Wednesday the stage was 6.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage tomorrow afternoon and continue rising to a crest of 10.5 feet Friday evening. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 6 at 9:12PM CST by NWS Corpus Christi TX
entry.summary:
Areas of fog are expected to develop across portions of South Texas tonight through Thursday morning. Expect visibilities generally 1 mile or less with a few locations seeing visibilities 1/4 mile or less at times.
Use caution if traveling as visibility may change rapidly in a short amount of time. Use low beam headlights and leave extra distance between your vehicle and others on the road.

entry.summary:

* WHEN...From Thursday morning to late Saturday evening.

Businesses and homes will be impacted on streets including but not limited to the following, in Warwick, Pioneer Avenue, Bellows Street, Venturi Avenue, and River Street. entry.summary:

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 6 at 5:49PM AKST until March 7 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...ACCUMULATING SNOW CONTINUES FOR THE PANHANDLE...
.A frontal band continues to move through the northern panhandle and will bring accumulating snow. Temperatures have warmed into the mid 30s for much of the south and outer coast, with rain mixing in with the snow for these locations at times. High snow ratios due to dry snow in the northern panhandle and Juneau area have led to higher than expected snow accumulations.
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 5 inches.
* WHERE...Municipality of Skagway and Haines Borough and Klukwan.
* WHEN...until 3 AM AKST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Powdery snow will accumulate quickly.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Light and dry snow will become increasingly wet though the night. Snow amounts may be higher than expected due to dry snow accumulating quickly.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 6 at 9:00PM EST until March 7 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
Low pressure brings another round of rainfall tonight into Thursday. Soils are saturated following recent rainfall, and flooding is possible from this system with a widespread 1.5 to 2.0 in of rainfall expected, with locally higher amounts. Additionally, snowmelt across interior locations will add additional runoff to area streams and rivers.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Maine, including the following areas, Androscoggin, Central Interior Cumberland, Coastal Cumberland, Coastal Waldo, Coastal York, Interior Cumberland Highlands, Interior Waldo, Interior York, Kennebec, Knox, Lincoln, Northern Franklin, Northern Oxford, Sagadahoc, Southern Franklin, Southern Oxford and Southern Somerset and New Hampshire, including the following areas, Belknap, Cheshire, Coastal Rockingham, Eastern Hillsborough, Interior Rockingham, Merrimack, Northern Carroll, Northern Grafton, Southern Carroll, Southern Grafton, Strafford, Sullivan and Western And Central Hillsborough.
* WHEN...Through Thursday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Some urban areas may flood as well.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rain and snowmelt.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 6 at 2:49PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A deep arctic trough will move south over the Western Interior and West Coast and bring well below normal temperatures beginning Friday night. High pressure over the Chukchi Sea will bring strong north winds starting Friday night as well. Low temperatures by Saturday morning will be in the teens and 20s below zero and remain that way through Wednesday morning. Highs will range from near zero to 10 below. North winds of 10 to 30 mph with higher gusts will bring wind chills as low as the 40s to near 50 below zero.
Residents and those traveling in the area are encouraged to be prepared for much colder than normal conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range; Noatak Valley; Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Upper Kobuk Valleys; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; Lower Yukon River; St Lawrence Island; Lower Koyukuk Valley; Middle Yukon Valley; Lower Yukon and Innoko Valleys

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 6 at 3:01PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
ESFBIS
Given the recent cold weather, the Missouri River has again been forming ice below Garrison Dam. Thus far, ice has filled the recently cleared portion of the Missouri River from roughly Apple Creek Wildlife Management Area to about three-fourths of a mile upstream of where 12th street southeast turns into Oahe Bend. This would roughly be equal to a little less than five miles of new ice in the river.
The upstream edge of immobile ice as of Wednesday morning was roughly three and a half miles downstream of Fort Abraham Lincoln and Fox Island. While the future rate of ice formation is difficult to predict, forecast overnight lows in the single digits for both Thursday and Friday mornings will continue to encourage ice formation. It should be expected that the upstream edge of continuous ice on the river will migrate upstream. Based on how much ice has already been put in place, it is possible that the upstream edge of continuous ice will reach the Fox Island area before warmer weather enters the area on Friday. By late Saturday, warmer weather will once again reverse this process and start removing ice.
Importantly, pre-ice river levels were about 3.5 feet below that observed prior to last week's ice jam due to already planned lower releases out of Garrison Dam. This suggests that a return to water levels experienced in late February is not likely.

cap:parameter.value: MISSOURI RIVER IS ONCE AGAIN MAKING ICE

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued March 6 at 5:12AM MST by NWS Billings MT
entry.summary:
AVWBYZ
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center.
The Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center is issuing a Backcountry Avalanche Warning for the mountains around Cooke City, the Lionhead area near West Yellowstone, and Island Park, ID. A foot of snow has fallen in the last 24 hours with blustery wind. The snowpack is weak and the new snow and wind-loading are creating very dangerous avalanche conditions. Human-triggered and natural avalanches are likely. Avoid avalanche terrain and avalanche runout zones. The avalanche danger is HIGH on all slopes. Contact the Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center for more detailed information.
Website: www.mtavalanche.com Avalanche Hotline: 406-587-6981
This warning will expire or be updated by 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, March 7th.
